Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and expression, creating two classes of citizens with different rights.
The internet is a democratic platform that should not be restricted by such legislation.
Excessive fines and lack of checks and balances will stifle free expression.
Determining truth is complex and censoring based on perceived misinformation is flawed.
The bill's broad definitions could unfairly target community websites and impose unreasonable burdens.
Extraterritorial application is impractical and risks isolating Australia from the global internet.
The bill contradicts democratic values and could lead to biased news coverage.
It raises constitutional concerns by delegating power to private entities and restricting political communication.
The bill disregards international commitments to human rights and freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: This bill undermines the very essence of democracy and poses a significant threat to the rights of regular citizens.
Censoring content based on perceived misinformation is an arbitrary and flawed approach.
The proposed extraterritorial application of the bill is an overreach by Australia on the global Internet.
